Traditionally placed in the genus Kachuga, it was assigned to the subgenus Pangshura by Moll (1987); Pangshura was elevated to genus level by Das (2001).
De la Riva (2005) resurrected Telmatobius sanborni from the synonymy of Telmatobius marmoratus on the basis of differences in morphological features and colour patterns.
Generally considered to consist of at least two morphologically distinguishable lineages.

There is evidence that the Discus Stingray (Paratrygon aiereba) comprises a species complex with genetically differentiated populations between river basins (Frederico et al. 2012, Fontenelle et al. 2021). The genus Paratrygon was considered monotypic, however, two new species from the Orinoco Basin (Paratrygon orinocensis and Paratrygon parvaspina) were described (Loboda et al. 2021).

There was a proposal to describe other species belonging to the genus Paratrygon. There seems to be evidence of other endemic lineages associated to certain Amazonian River basins, such as in Branco and Rupunini rivers, Negro-Peru River, Tapajós River, Araguaia River, Tocantins River and Xingu River (Loboda 2016, Fontenelle et al. 2021). Until these endemic lineages are formally described, the genus Paratrygon is considered to comprise three species: P. aiereba (Amazon River main channel and some of its larger tributaries), P. orinocensis and P. parvaspina (Orinoco River Basin).
The conservation assessment of this taxon is complicated by the conviction that the current taxonomic designation hides a complex of several different species.

taxonomicNotes: This species is one of many small Hydrobids that can be most easily be identified using anatomical characters of the reproductive system, however, these species are in urgent need of a review incorporating conchological characters, anatomical characters and molecular characters in order to understand the relationships with other taxa (Haase et al. 2007).

This species was previously referred to as Hetereleotris sticta (Hoese and Larson 2005, Randall 2006). Randall (2006) questioned the suitability of this species' name due to its similarity to Pascua caudilinea. It will likely be placed in a different genus (D. Hoese and H.K. Larson pers. comm. 2024).
This species was split from Eleutherodactylus ruthae (Hedges et al. 2008).
This species was split from Eleutherodactylus ruthae by Hedges et al. (2008), but further work suggests it is likely a synonym of E. ruthae (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2021).

This species was formerly recognized as subspecies of Eleutherodactylus schmidti (Schwartz 1971), Hedges et al. (2008) formalized the species status of this taxon.

In some published literature, this taxon is referred to as a subpopulation or subspecies of the European Cisco (Coregonus albula).

At the regional scale, the systematics of European ciscoes and whitefishes (Coregonus spp.) has been the subject of considerable debate since the turn of the 21st century, with little indication of a definitive outcome.

It is widely accepted that non-anadromous members of this group have repeatedly undergone adaptive radiations in boreal, subarctic and perialpine lakes (Douglas et al. 1999, Østbye et al. 2005, Kahilainen and Østbye 2006, Harrod et al. 2010, Hudson et al. 2011).

Subpopulations inhabiting these systems largely diversified in the wake of the most recent glacial period 10,000-15,000 years ago. They are typified by parallel patterns of divergence in traits associated with foraging (i.e., gill raker counts, benthic vs. pelagic feeding ecology), physiology (i.e., growth rate, habitat depth partitioning) and reproductive ecology (i.e., reproductive timing and spawning habitat).

Up to six different sympatric forms sometimes referred to as “morphs”, "ecomorphs" or "ecotypes" have been recorded in perialpine lakes, and these radiations might be even more diverse in some large systems of northeastern Europe (Præbel et al. 2013, Doenz et al. 2018, Bitz‐Thorsen et al. 2020, Öhlund et al. 2020).

However, there exist significant differences in opinion regarding the taxonomic status of these forms.

In Northern Europe, including the United Kingdom, all except a handful of Irish subpopulations are usually regarded as belonging to two widely-distributed species; Coregonus albula (ciscoes) and C. lavaretus (whitefishes), with the latter also frequently referred to as the "Coregonus lavaretus species complex” (Etheridge et al. 2012, Wanke et al. 2017, Häkli et al. 2018, Crotti et al. 2020). Within this comparatively uniform taxonomic concept, the catch-all English vernacular name “Vendace” is typically used for C. albula while "Common Whitefish" or "European Whitefish" are applied to C. lavaretus.

Conversely, researchers and fisheries authorities based in Central Europe have tended to treat the different forms as distinct taxa, leading to the recognition of more than 60 species across the European region (Kottelat and Freyhof 2007, Selz et al. 2020, De-Kayne et al. 2022, Selz and Seehausen 2023). Under this diverse taxonomic concept, the name “Vendace” is restricted to its original usage for the United Kingdom endemic Coregonus vandesius and the native range of C. lavaretus is limited to its type locality of Lake Bourget in France.

With the above in mind, it appears unlikely that the striking phenotypic diversity exhibited by members of this genus will ever be adequately represented by a single accepted taxonomic system. In the absence of a region-wide consensus, the IUCN Red List broadly follows the taxonomy provided by Fricke et al. (2024).
Prior to its description by Köhler (2009), this species was referred to as a population of Anolis altae.

Anderson (1875) described it as Trionyx nigricans from the pond at the Hazrat Sultan Bayazid Bostami Shrine in Nasirabad near Chittagong, Bangladesh. Subsequent authors believed that the species either became extinct in the wild (Pritchard 1979, Groombridge 1982) or that it ‘descended from introduced individuals of the more widespread Trionyx gangeticus’ (Groombridge 1982, Khan 1987) or of N. hurum (Rashid 1990). Using mainly skull osteology as well as coloration and pattern characters, Praschag and Gemel (2002) recognized it from northeast India as Aspideretes nigricans. Based on molecular data, Engstrom et al. (2004) and Praschag et al. (2007) transferred the genus Aspideretes Hay, 1903 into synonymy of Nilssonia (Gray, 1872). See Praschag and Gemel (2002) for discussion of taxonomic distinction from other large Asian softshell species.
Appeared in IUCN Red Lists prior to 2007 under the generic names Heosemys and Geoemyda.

Le et al. (2014) concluded that the Yangtze and Red River subpopulations of Rafetus swinhoei do not show significant genetic divergence and do not warrant recognition as separate evolutionary significant units for conservation management. However, it appears that Le et al. (2014) did not actually have any samples from the Yangtze subpopulation, only samples from the Vietnamese and Chinese parts of the Red River catchment. Chen (2015) found two distinct mtDNA lineages of R. swinhoei which are roughly 2.8% divergent from each other (Cytochrome B and NADH dehydrogenase 4), one represented by Red River specimens and the second one by a Shanghai museum specimen of unknown origin. In the meantime, tissue samples from the male of Suzhou Zoo and the female of Changsha Zoo proved to be concordant with the Shanghai museum specimen (H. Chen pers. comm.). This points to a possibility that the Yangtze and the Red River subpopulations may represent separate taxa at least at the level of subspecies. In that case the Yangtze subpopulation would represent the nominate form Rafetus swinhoei swinhoei and the Vietnamese and Chinese Red River subpopulation the subspecies Rafetus swinhoei leloii.

Was treated under the generic name Geoemyda in the 1996 IUCN Red List. The genus was changed to Heosemys in the 2000 IUCN Red List. Now reassigned to a new monotypic genus, Leucocephalon (A. Rhodin pers. comm.).
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

It has been suggested that this species is not native to Martinique, but is synonymous with another species from South America (M. Breuil pers. comm., Breuil 2009); however, following its rediscovery in October 2012 (Dewynter et al. 2012), new genetic material and phylogenetic analysis confirmed that it is nested within a clade of lowland Amazonian Allobates but nonetheless distantly related to any known species of the group (Fouquet et al. 2013). In addition, the arrival of the species in Martinique likely corresponds to an overseas dispersal from South America during the late Miocene, as previously hypothesized for Bothrops lanceolatus and Leptodactylus fallax, two other species endemic to Martinique and surrounding islands (Fouquet et al. 2013).

This species was previously within the genus Phyllomedusa but was moved to the genus Hylomantis by Faivovich et al. (2005). Subsequently, it was moved from Hylomantis to Agalychnis by Favivovich et al. (2010).
Genetic data indicate that this is a complex of species occurring in isolated, montane areas, each highly threatened (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2021).
A specimen recorded from Forêt des Pins National Park in Haiti may belong to this taxon, but further research is needed to clarify this (C. Martínez Rivera pers. comm. 2020).

This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). Genetic analysis of animals in the captive collection may represent disparate cryptic species (Crawford et al. 2013).
This taxon is presently considered valid, but is very likely to be a junior synonym of Eleutherodactylus weinlandi based on genetics and morphology (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2021).
This taxon is very likely a junior synonym of Eleutherodactylus glandulifer (Hispaniola Red List Assessment Workshop 2020; S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2021).
Castro (2011) resurrected Carcharhinus cerdale, considering it distinct from C. porosus. Carcharhinus cerdale is restricted to the Eastern Pacific and C. porosus to the Western Atlantic.

Dipturus diehli Soto & Mincarone, 2001, as known only from the holotype taken off Santa Catarina, Brazil (29°39´S, 47°50´W) at a depth of 480 m, is likely a synonym of D. mennii and is treated here as such.
Without knowledge of calls or habitat this species cannot be readily separated from Eleutherodactylus gossei (Schwartz and Fowler 1973).

The Desert Tortoise was previously considered to be a single wide-ranging species, Gopherus agassizii (sensu lato), inhabiting the Mojave and Sonoran Desert regions of the southwestern USA and northwestern Mexico (Iverson 1992). The species was eventually found to be polytypic, and Murphy et al. (2011) split out the morphologically and genetically distinct Sonoran Desert subpopulations as Gopherus morafkai, the Sonoran Desert Tortoise. Further analysis demonstrated that G. morafkai was also polytypic and therefore split further to separate and describe the Sinaloan Thornscrub Tortoise further to the south as G. evgoodei (Edwards et al. 2016). This taxonomy of three species of desert tortoises has been accepted by TTWG (2017) and Berry and Murphy (2019).

McCranie (2011) proposed elevating Cubophis canthigerus brooksi to specific status following the recognition by Hedges et al. (2009) that Cayman Island populations also previously included within C. canthigerus are genetically distinct from this species. Although Hedges et al. (2009) did not consider the status of the Honduran population, McCranie (2011) notes that it is geographically closer to the Cayman Islands than to Cuban C. canthigerus, and so it is implausible that C. canthigerus and C. brooksi are conspecific.
The supopulation in Atewa, Ghana is most likely a separate species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016).

Bour et al. (1995) elevated the the subspecies Phelsuma ornata inexpectata to species rank, based on coloration and biological criteria. Phylogenetic studies confirm that this taxon is well-differentiated from Mauritian P. ornata (Austin et al. 2004), and it is currently accepted as a full species by most herpetologists.

The taxonomy of spider monkeys (Ateles spp.) is based on Kellogg and Goldman´s (1944) seminal review, and more recently complemented by morphological and molecular analysis of Froehlich et al. (1991), Collins and Dubach (2000), Nieves et al. (2005) and Morales-Jimenez et al. (2015). In all studies, brown spider monkeys (Ateles hybridus I. Geoffroy, 1829) form a monophyletic clade, justifying full species status following the molecular studies conducted by Collins (1999) and Collins and Dubach (2000). These studies found that brown spider monkeys form an ancient clade within the spider monkeys, separated from white-bellied spider monkeys (Ateles belzebuth) approximately 3 mya. This classification was reinforced by Nieves et al. (2005) using chromosomal and molecular markers. Hernández-Camacho and Defler (1989) and Defler (2004) argued for the validity of two distinct forms: brunneus Gray, 1872 from the western bank of the Magdalena River, and hybridus from the eastern bank of the Magdalena River in Colombia and Venezuela. Nonetheless, recent molecular studies using two mitochondrial markers suggest that there has been substantial gene flow between both populations and that both taxa do not represent monophyletic clades (Link et al. 2015). Thus, brown spider monkeys are currently considered a single taxon without subspecific divisions.

There is a single record of a hybrid Red-shanked Douc (Pygathrix nemaeus) X Grey-shanked Douc (P. cinerea) in northeastern Cambodia (Rawson and Roos 2008). Current knowledge of the zones of transition between the three douc taxa is unclear, with limited information mostly based on brief field views (Timmins and Duckworth 1999, Nadler et al. 2004, Rawson and Roos 2008). There may be a zone in Viet Nam with sympatry (and possibly hybridization) between the three taxa (Lippold et al. 2011). Both Black-shanked Douc (P. nigripes) and Grey-shanked Douc were previously considered conspecific with Red-shanked Douc

In the past this taxon has been considered either a subspecies of Pygathrix nemaeus, or a hybrid of P. nemaeus and P. nigripes (Nadler 1995). Other studies on the genetics of doucs show that P. cinerea and P. nemaeus are sister taxa (Roos and Nadler 2001). There is strong evidence that this taxon hybridizes with Red-shanked Doucs (P. nemaeus) in a small sympatric distribution area of Quang Nam Province (Nadler 1997) and possibly in northeast Cambodia (Rawson and Roos 2008).

authority: Geissmann, Ngwe Lwin, Saw Soe Aung, Thet Naing Aung, Zin Myo Aung, Tony Htin Hla, Grindley & Momberg, 2011
taxonomicNotes:
This is a recently described species of Snub-nosed Monkey from the high altitudes of northeastern Kachin state, northeastern Myanmar. Descriptions are based on a skin and skulls of four specimens obtained from local hunters. The new species is geographically isolated from other Snub-nosed Monkeys and separated from them by two major barriers the Mekong and the Salween (Thanlwin) rivers.

It is closely related to Rhinopithecus bieti
This species was formerly considered to be in the genus Pygathrix.

Until relatively recently, Macaca pagensis included M. siberu (Roos et al. 2003). It is now considered a separate species from M. siberu due to genetic and morphological difference. Earlier it was considered as a subspecies of M. nemestrina until established as a separate species.

Individuals with intermediate characteristics, presumably hybrids, have historically been seen along the border of this species' range and that of Macaca nigrescens (although this contact zone may no longer exist; Sugardjito et al. 1989). The zone of intergradation is the downstream region of the Onggak Dumoga River and Groves (1980) placed M. nigrescens as a subspecies of M. nigra. Despite the morphological and genetical similarity, M. nigra and M. nigrescens are still distinct and therefore classified as distinct species (Groves 2001). Macaca nigra belongs to the silenus group including M. pagensis, M. siberu, M. leonina, M. silenus, and M. nemestrina.

This species was formerly placed in the genus Nasalis. Recent molecular analysis suggest a close relationship between Simias and Nasalis, however, current classification still places Simias concolor in its own genus (Whittaker et al. 2006). To date, two subspecies are recognised, primarily based on slight differences in pelage colouration: S. c. concolor, which is found in Indonesia on the islands of Sipora, North Pagai, as well as South Pagai, and S. c. siberu, which is exclusively found on the island of Siberut (Miller 1903, Chasen and Kloss 1927).
Presbytis potenziani is now monotypic and the former subspecies P. p. siberu is now a distinct species.

This taxon was formerly considered a subspecies of Presbytis femoralis and P. melalophos. The number of subspecies is disputed. In addition to the two generally recognized forms (Presbytis chrysomelas chrysomelas and P. c. cruciger) there is an additional, isolated population found only in a small area of southeastern Sarawak (Betong, Saribas; Nimong; Batang Lupar) that probably represents an as yet undescribed subspecies (Groves 2001).

This taxon was formerly considered as a subspecies of Trachypithecus francoisi. The taxon was elevated to species level by Brandon-Jones (1984) and Groves (2001), the later conclusion being supported by molecular genetic studies (Roos 2003, 2004) and parasitological findings (May 1994).

Previously four subspecies were recognised (N. c. concolor, N. c. furvogaster, N. c. jingdongensis and N. c. lu) (Ma and Wang 1986), however N. c. furvogaster of south-western Yunnan, west of Mekong River and N. c. jingdonensis of west central Yunnan, China are now considered synonomous with the nominate form while N. c. lu is recognised as a valid subspecies (Thinh et al 2010a,b).

This taxon was variously considered a subspecies of N. concolor, N. leucogenys and N. gabriellae. It was believed that N. siki might be a natural hybrid of N. leucogenys and N. gabriellae but this is due to missing information in the past. Genetic and acoustic data clearly show that this taxon is a valid species (Thinh et al. 2010a, Thinh et al. 2010b, Thinh et al. 2011).

The recent discovery of N. annamensis and the extended southward distribution of N. leucogenys have largely reduced the distribution of the species. The limits of distribution of this species are not finally settled, both with regards to N. annamensis in the south and N. leucogenys in the north. Similarly, phenotype information for the type locality of N. siki (Thua Luu, Thua Thien Hue province, central Viet Nam) is contradictory (Geissmann et al. 2000; Thinh et al. 2010b). Though the holotype represents N. siki morphologically, the type locality falls in the range of N. annamensis (Thinh et al. 2010a). Recent genetic data of the N. siki holotype clearly confirm that this specimen is N. siki (C. Roos pers. comm.). Unfortunately, information about whether Jean Delacour and Pierre Jabouille collected the specimen in the wild near Thua Luu or whether they obtained the gibbon at a market or from a poacher is not traceable. However, since Thua Luu is close to the coast and along the Vietnamese national railway line and the national road no. 1, and considering the morphology and genetic data of the holotype, the specimen most likely originated from a place other than Thua Luu.

Nomascus nasutus has been variously considered either as a species in its own right (sometimes as conspecific with N. hainanus), or as a subspecies of N. concolor; it is here recognized as a species distinct from N. hainanus and N. concolor, based on differences in vocalizations and fur colouration as well as genetic evidence (Mootnick and Fan 2011; Van Ngoc Thinh et al. 2010, 2011; Feng et al. 2014).

Recognized as a valid species by Hershkovitz (1990). Byrne et al. (2016) split the genus Callicebus into three new genera, namely: Cheracebus (torquatus-group sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002), Plecturocebus (cupreus-, moloch-, donacophilus-groups sensu Roosmalen et al. (2002) and Callicebus (personatus-group, sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002). According to Byrne et al. (2016) , Plecturocebus includes 22 species.

This species was previously known as Callicebus olallae (Lönnberg 1939). Taxonomical assessments of titi monkeys recognized different number of species groups (Hershkosvitz 1963, 1988, 1990, Kobayashi 1995, Kobayashi and Langguth 1999, van Roosmalen et al. 2002, Groves 2005). A completely new phylogenetic arrangement of these primates (Byrne et al. 2016), divides Callicebus into three genera: Cheracebus, Callicebus, and Plecturocebus. According to this last assessment, Plecturocebus olallae is found in the donacophilus group, along with P. donacophilus, P. modestus, P. oenanthe, P. pallescens and P. urubambensis.The morphological similarity between P. olallae and P. modestus demanded further investigation (Tarifa 1996, Anderson 1997, Felton et al. 2006). Recent field observations (Martinez and Wallace 2007), as well as opportunistically collected specimens (Martinez et al. 2013), and results from a scat-based genetic study (Wallace et al. 2013, Barreta et al. 2019) support the taxonomic separation of P. olallae and P. modestus.

Meyer (1897) classified a single specimen from Siau Island together with several others from Sangihe Island as Tarsius sangirensis. A biogeographic hypothesis by Shekelle and Leksono (2004) predicted that the Siau specimen would be taxonomically distinct (see also Brandon Jones et al. 2004). This prediction was subsequently confirmed by Shekelle et al. (2008). The Sangir and Siau islands are separated by ca 60 km of ocean with depths >1,000 m and therefore no possible recurrent gene flow between T. sangirensis and T. tumpara.

Although closely related to, and for long considered to be a subspecies of Trachypithecus poliocephalus Trouessart, 1911 (see Groves 2001, 2005; Roos et al. 2007), Groves (2001) argued that it may be a distinct species, not least because of consistent differences in pelage colour patterns. Groves (2007) and Nadler (2013) considered it to be a full species (also Roos et al. 2014). Trachypithecus leucocephalus interbreeds with T. francoisi south and east of the Zuo River in Guangxi, China (Groves 2001).
No synonyms or subspecies of Kinixys homeana have been described, and no geographic variation is known.
There are three recognized subspecies: Dicerorhinus sumatrensis lasiotis (probably extinct), Dicerorhinus sumatrensis sumatrensis, and Dicerorhinus sumatrensis harrissoni.

A collection in the Northern Cape from 1996 has been excluded from the assessment as it might have been misidentified (Hamer & Rayner, 1996). It is suspected that the record may belong to Streptocephalus valkyrie, a recently described species that closely resembles S. gracilis (Rogers and Meyer-Milne 2021). In recent surveys in the Western Cape Province, within the known location for this species, it was not collected (De Roeck et al. 2007).

Earlier speculation that there were significant differences in genetic diversity among populations proved unfounded, and the low levels of genetic differentiation do not warrant separation of Chalinolobus tuberculatus into subspecies (Dool et al. 2016, O’Donnell et al. 2016).
Pteropus howensis might be conspecific with P. admiralitatum; this needs further study. It is treated provisionally here as a separate species following Simmons (2005).
The molecular and morphological distinction from other species in the Hipposideros ruber complex has recently been described (Monadjem et al. 2013).
Reviewed by Gromov and Erbajeva (1995) and Shenbrot et al. (1995).
According to Nanova 2014, the species rank of Meriones dahli requires verification with genetic data.
Sometimes known as Cephaloscyllium sarawakense (Fricke et al. 2020).

Based on morphological analysis Hedges and Conn (2012) removed Mabuya dominicana from synonymy with M. mabouia (which they restricted to Martinique) and recognized six additional new species from within this complex, four of which (M. desiradae, M. guadeloupae, M. grandisterrae and M. cochonae) they assigned to the "M. guadeloupae species group" based on morphological differences between taxa from the Guadeloupe archipelago and those elsewhere. Subsequently, Hedges et al. (2016) included material of M. desiradae in both morphological and molecular analyses, the results of which led to Hedges et al. (2016) recognizing a population from Iles de la Petite Terre as a separate species, M. parviterrae, specifically distinct from M. desiradae from La Désirade.

Unfortunately most of these taxa are now either extinct or extremely rare, and as such the sample sizes used to distinguish these species were very small (five or fewer specimens for every member of the M. guadeloupae group), which A. Miralles (pers. comm. 2018) suggests is not sufficient to obtain statistically meaningful results.. This data limitation, along with the discovery of an additional related population from Iles des Saintes (Angin and Gomès 2015, Gomès and Ibéné 2015) has led to subsequent disagreements about the systematics of this group:  Miralles et al. (2017) proposed recognizing a single species for the archipelago (for which they selected the name M. desiradae), including M. parviterrae and the three taxa for which molecular data were not available: M. cochonae, M. grandisterrae and M. guadeloupae, a scheme subsequently rejected by Hedges et al. (2019).

These accounts follow the multispecies taxonomy presented by Hedges and Conn (2012), Hedges et al. (2016) and Hedges et al. (2019) but recognize that an accurate resolution of the taxonomy of this group may never be possible.
Neobola fluviatilis was thought to occur in several rivers in Kenya (Whitehead 1962). Recent work restrict N. fluviatilis to the Athi River (Bart et al. 2019).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Andrias sligoi (Turvey et al. 2019).

Four subspecies have been described: Peltophryne longinasus longinasus in Pinar del Río; P. l. cajalbanensis in the Cajálbana Plateau, also in Pinar del Río; P. l. dunni in the mountains of Guamuhaya; and P. l. ramsdeni in the Sierra del Guaso (González Alonso et al. 2012). Two of the subspecies (dunni and ramsdeni) have been elevated to species status (Hedges et al. 2019).

Brodie et al. (2012) described this species from a locality in the Guatemalan portion of Cerro Montecristo. A series of morphologically similar salamanders is available from the Honduran side of Cerro Montecristo. DNA data from one of those Honduran specimens was reported on by García-París and Wake (2000; as Oedipina sp. B). McCranie (2006) and McCranie and Castañeda (2007) had identified those salamanders as O. ignea. There is no reason to expect that the Honduran Cerro Montecristo species is not conspecific with those on the Guatemalan side of that same mountain range (although the Guatemalan locality for this species is in open pine forest [see Brodie et al. 2012, 238] and the Honduran locality assigned to O. chortiorum were found in Mesic broadleaf forest.
The taxonomic validity of this species is confirmed, on the basis of morphology, allozymes, and mtDNA (H.B. Shaffer pers. comm.).

Groves (2001), Grubb et al. (2003), and Kingdon et al. (2008) treat Erythrocebus patas as a monotypic species in a monotypic genus. Schwarz (1927), Isbell (2013), and De Jong and Butynski (2018) recognize baumstarki as one of the three subspecies within E. patas (patas, pyrrhonotus, baumstarki). Verheyen (1962), Hill (1966), Napier and Napier (1967), Dandelot (1968, 1974), and Kingdon (1971, 1997, 2015) recognize an additional subspecies, E. p. villiersi.

Erythrocebus baumstarki was described by Matschie (1906) as a species (type locality: Ikoma, western Serengeti, Tanzania). Here, baumstarki is, once again, treated as a species. This restoration to species status is based on baumstarki’s considerable geographic isolation and distinctive coloration and pattern of the pelage. The distance between the nearest confirmed E. baumstarki record (Northern Extension of Serengeti National Park, north central Tanzania; G. Schaller pers. comm.; number 15 in Figure 1 and Table 1 of De Jong et al. 2009) and the nearest confirmed E. p. pyrrhonotus record (Kiganjo, central Kenya; H. Douglas-Dufresne pers. comm.; number 47 in Figure 2 and Table 3 in De Jong et al. 2008) is ca. 260 km. There are, however, several records between these two localities for Erythrocebus that have not been identified as to species (De Jong et al. 2008). It appears that these two species are separated by a forest barrier and by very dry habitat in the Eastern (Gregory) Rift Valley (De Jong et al. 2008, 2009, De Jong & Butynski 2014, Butynski & De Jong 2017). Erythrocebus baumstarki is also phenotypically distinct (e.g., black nose, lack of white moustache, pale red crown, white neck, and dark grey upper limbs, whereas pyrrhonotus has a white nose, white moustache, dark red crown, rufous neck, and lacks dark grey on the upper hind legs). Resurrecting baumstarki to species status is in agreement with Gippoliti (2017), who suggests treating baumstarki, as well as poliophaeus and pyrrhonotus, as species.

Pristimantis riveti was described from a single specimen collected in Ecuador, El Mirador (Despax 1911). This species name was not associated with any population until Lynch (1969) incorrectly identified subpopulations of P. curtipes as “P. riveti” (Lynch 1979). Subsequently, Lynch (1979) provided a species account based on specimens collected near Cuenca, Azuay Province, in southern Ecuador, but remarkably, excluded the type locality from his account. Subsequent references to the species (e.g., Almendáriz and Orcés 2004, Székely et al. 2016) relied on the morphological characterization provided by Lynch (1979) and ascribed the binomen to subpopulations from Azuay, Cañar and Loja Provinces. 

Various species (e.g., P. gloria, P. lutzae, P. multicolor and P. chomskyi) have been mistakenly identified as P. riveti (Páez and Ron 2019). Therefore, this is a restricted concept of Pristimantis riveti following the split of the broader concept into this, P. gloria, P. lutzae, P. multicolor and P. chomskyi (Páez and Ron 2019).

The assessments for this group nonetheless follow the taxonomy proposed by Horner (2007) pending a more detailed revision of Indian Ocean Crypotoblepharus. Prior to the Horner revision, specific status was previously proposed for the Madagascan C. cognatus and C. voeltzkowi and supported by significant morphological differences (Andreone and Greer 2002), but this has not been widely adopted within the region and the taxonomy of these forms remains among the most controversial in the genus.


Recent genetic evidence from a biogeographic paper (Blom et al. 2019) confirms that genetic divergence within Indian Ocean Cryptoblepharus is low, but does not sample all nominal taxa and their results suggest that divergence - including that between C. cognatus and C. voeltzkowi - is comparable to that among Pacific Cryptoblepharus lineages recognized as full species (G. Shea pers. comm. 2020).

Hershkovitz (1949) divided the so-called “untufted capuchin monkeys” into three species, capucinus, nigrivittatus and albifrons, distinguishing them by the shape of the dark patch on the crown: albifrons rounded and nigrivittatus wedge shaped. On this basis, he considered trinitatis Von Pusch, restricted to the island of Trinidad, to be a subspecies of Cebus albifrons, despite the fact that it was completely isolated from albifrons by the various subspecies that he listed of the wedge-capped capuchins, Cebus nigrivittatus (now considered olivaceus), on the Guiana Shield in Venezuela, Brazil, Guyana, Suriname and French Guiana.  Subspecies of Cebus albifrons in his taxonomic arrangement otherwise occurred south of the Rio Amazonas-Solimões in Brazil, and in the upper Amazon, north and south of the Rio Amazonas in Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Bolivia, west of the Andes in Ecuador and Tumbes, northern Peru, and in northern Colombia. The “nearest known relatives of trinitatis occur in the upper Orinoco region (albifrons) and in the Lake Maracaibo region (adustus)”, which indicated that trinitatis is an introduced population (Hershkovitz, 1949, p. 38). Hill (1960) and Groves (2001, 2005) followed Hershkovitz in listing trinitatis as a subspecies of C. albifrons.

In the first phylogenetic analysis of the genus, Cebus trinitatis and the form brunneus Allen, 1914, from northern Venezuela and considered by Hershkovitz to be a subspecies of C. nigrivittatus, were found to be very closely related, and in the albifrons clade rather than that of the wedge-capped capuchins (Boubli et al., 2o12).  Boubli et al. (2012) suggested that trinitatis might be a junior synonym. The two capuchin monkeys are, however, quite distinct in appearance, and evidence for the synonymy of trinitatis is as yet inconclusive (J. P. Boubli and J. Lynch Alfaro, pers. comm. February 2021). In fact upon subsequent morphological inspection, the C. brunneus sampled from the Smithsonian for the genetic study of Boubli et al. 2012, are not the same species as the type specimens of brunneus (which are olivaceus-like) at the American Museum of Natural History, despite their very close geographic provenance to those C. brunneus specimens; the samples from the Boubli et al. (2012) are more similar to C. adustus and C. leucocephalus in morphology, but extend the range of the albifrons-like monkeys to the east of the Andes on the Venezuelan coast. Thus, the IUCN SSC Primate Specialist Group maintains trinitatus as a separate taxon, with affinities to the Andes albifrons-like species.

Johnson et al. (2008) did not find evidence to support Eulemur cinereiceps as a separate taxon from E. albocollaris, and that priority should be given to the senior synonym, E. cinereiceps, as the valid name.

This species was previously considered to be a subspecies of Eulemur macaco. After the elevation of all former E. fulvus subspecies to full species status (Mittermeier et al. 2006), E. macaco remained the only member of the genus that was divided into subspecies (E. m. macaco and E. m. flavifrons). Taking into account the consistency of the morphological differences between the Black Lemur and the Blue-eyed Black Lemur, the retention of this taxonomy is inappropriate. The pairwise genetic distances between macaco and flavifrons are 68–72 bp, which is in the same range as between the former E. fulvus subspecies (29–90 bp, according to Pastorini 2000). Some earlier authors suggested a geographical cline in subspecific traits over a relatively large area of their distribution border (Meyers et al. 1989, Rabarivola et al. 1991), but more recent surveys suggest that the zone of hybridization between the two taxa is restricted to the north-eastern part of the distribution of E. flavifrons (Andrianjakarivelo 2004; Schwitzer et al. 2005, 2006). Based on these findings, and in order to restore a consistent taxonomy of Eulemur, the Blue-eyed Black Lemur was raised to full species status by Mittermeier et al. (2008, 2010).

Two subspecies have been proposed (Groves 2001), however, this is not supported by morphological (Zaonarivelo et al. 2007) or genetic (Brenneman et al. 2016) analysis, supporting the opinion that the two major colour forms are merely part of a clinal variation and not indicative of distinct taxa (Brenneman et al. 2016).

(2002) argued that it deserved species status, recently supported by the craniometric study of Groves and Helgen (2007) which found this species to have highly distinctive cranial features.

Formerly included as a subspecies of Propithecus verreauxi (e.g. Groves 1993), or as the nominate subspecies of P. deckenii (e.g. Groves 2001), and genetically virtually indistinguishable from P. coronatus and P. verreauxi based on c. 2,400 bp of  mtDNA (Pastorini et al. 2001) or on complete mitochondrial cytochrome b sequences (Rumpler et al. 2011), but now generally considered a distinct species (e.g. Thalmann et al. 2002, Groves and Helgen 2007; but see Tattersall 2007). Former confusion over the distribution of this species and the closely related P. coronatus has been resolved by field studies by Rakotonirina et al. (2014) and King et al. (2014), however taxonomic field study is still needed to fully understand the relationship between the two species and the causes of the melanistic tendencies in these and other sifaka species (King et al. 2014, Rakotonirina et al. 2014).

In the forests of Tsinjoarivo in eastern central Madagascar (at the southern extreme of the species’ geographic range), an unusual population of what appears to be Propithecus diadema has been discovered. The animals are variably coloured, including all black individuals (several of which are known to have been born to parents with typical pelage), but preliminary genetic studies indicate that this population requires further study before subspecific status can be established (Mayor et al. 2004)

Taxonomic status for the genus Varecia have not been fully resolved at the genus or species level. Groves (2001) proposed full species status of Varecia variegata and Varecia rubra. As the most current analyses of Varecia variegata, Baden et al. 2014 presented evidence using microsatellite STR data that the genus Varecia variegata should only have two subspecies, V. v. editorum and V. v. variegata, stating that V. v. subcincta did not warrant subspecies/species status. Genomic level studies are currently underway, designed to resolve the taxonomic status and distribution of the genus Varecia using samples representing the entire range of all ruffed lemurs (E. Louis pers. comm.).

Zinner et al. (2007) examined conflicting results in the genetic analysis of sportive lemurs in northwestern Madagascar, those within the range of what once was considered to be Lepilemur dorsalis. Since the type localities of L. dorsalis Gray, 1871 and L. grandidieri Forsyth Major, 1894, were both “Northwest Madagascar”, the proper name of one or two of the new species from the region (sahamalazensis, grewcocki, mittermeieri, tymlerachsoni) could be either of these two. The true "dorsalis", as such, had not been identified, and no attempt has been made to identify grandidieri, formerly a junior synonym of dorsalis. Genetic analysis of the holotypes of dorsalis and grandidieri is needed to resolve this. Zinner et al. (2007) indicated, therefore, that tymerlachsoni and/or mittermeieri might be junior synonyms.

The Chilean Angelshark (Squatina armata), has previously been considered to be conspecific with the Pacific Angelshark (S. californica). Recent molecular evidence places S. armata as the sister taxon to the Neotropical angel sharks, indicating it is a distinct species (Stelbrink et al. 2010). Given its prior taxonomic placement, some literature on the elasmobranch fauna of Peru, Ecuador, and Colombia list S. californica as part of their coastal fauna, while others only mention S. armata. To add to the confusion, some country checklists include both S. armata and S. californica (see Cornejo et al. 2015). These records of S. californica occurring sympatrically with S. armata are likely incorrect, thus for the purpose of this assessment all angel shark records in the Southeast Pacific are considered to be S. armata. Further research is needed to elucidate the distributions of S. armata and S. californica, particularly in the Pacific coast of Central America and the northwest coast of South America.

Caledoniscincus constellatus (described in 2012) has a bold, white midlateral stripe, a feature which distinguishes it from most other species of Caledoniscincus except the regionally sympatric C. haplorhinus (Günther) and C. austrocaledonicus (Bavay), from which it can be distinguished by a unique pattern of contact between the pale midlateral stripe and the ear. DNA sequence data for the ND2 mitochondrial gene identifies a high level of genetic differentiation between the new species and all other Caledoniscincus, further supporting its distinctiveness as an independent evolutionary lineage.

Nannoscincus koniambo was described in 2014 (Sadlier, 2014). It is part of the N. mariei group, is restricted to the Koniambo massif and can be distinguished from all other members of the genus a combination of characters: frontoparietals fused; loreal single; left oviduct lost in females; lower labials five; lower eyelid with a semi-translucent window; ear opening minute; body scales smooth; adult dorsal color two toned; ear opening positioned two scales posterior to lower secondary temporal; presacral vertebrae 32; phalangeal formula for manus 2.3.4.4.3.; phalangeal formula for pes 2.3.4.5.3.

This specimen and others examined from Îlot Môrô are morphologically assignable to the species described by Boulenger in 1878 as Chameleonurus trachycephalus (and later treated as a subspecies of R. trachyrhynchus) and is now recognized as a full species (Bauer et al. 2012).

The common name in Vietnamese is Rua hop tran vang.

Glyphis gangeticus was originally described from the Hooghly River, India. Records of G. gangeticus are sparse and there have been previous issues with reporting due to misidentification with other carcharhinds, mainly the Bull Shark (Carcharhinus leucas) and Broadfin sharks (Lamiopsis spp.), resulting in historic ambiguities about the range of G. gangeticus. The taxonomic status of the species was recently resolved with Li et al. (2015) demonstrating that G. siamensis and G. fowlerae are synonyms of G. gangeticus. Based on molecular data, there is an undescribed Glyphis species currently known from Bangladesh and Malaysian Borneo (Li et al. 2015).
White (2014) placed the genus Pteromylaeus Garman, 1913 into the synonymy of Aetomylaeus Garman, 1908. This species is often confused with Common Eagle Ray (Myliobatus aquila).

It is unclear whether this, or a similar, species occurs along the east and west African coasts and Mediterranean Sea. A systematic review of this species is needed in these areas. This species is sometimes confused with Duckbill Eagle Ray (Aetomylaeus bovinus).

The Red Sea Torpedo (Torpedo suessii) is considered a valid species. It is known from only three specimens captured off Mocha, Yemen, in 1897 (Steindachner 1898) which are housed at Naturhistorisches Museum, Vienna, Austria.

Steindachner (1898) did not assign the holotype and paratypes but de Carvalho et al. (2002) nominated the lectotype (NMW 88240) and the paralectotype (NMW 78016) from Steindachner’s original specimens. Steindachner’s third specimen (NMW 87406) was recently rediscovered and assigned as a paralectotype (Palandačić et al. 2023). The Red Sea Torpedo can be differentiated from other torpedo rays in the Western Indian Ocean, the Red Sea, and nearby gulfs by its distinctive patterning consisting of eight, large brown spots (de Carvalho et al. 2002).

The Red Sea Torpedo was previously considered a junior synonym of T. sinuspersici (de Carvalho et al. 2002). Garman (1913) considered T. suessii to be a valid species but postulated that it may be synonymous with T. panthera. It is however unlikely that the ornate colour pattern of T. suessii could morph into the small, irregular whitish spots typical of both juvenile and adult T. panthera (de Carvalho et al. 2002).

A recent systematic revision by Carranza et al. (2016), using an integrative approach including molecular (mitochondrial and nuclear markers) and morphological data, indicated that the species originally classified as Asaccus caudivolvulus (Arnold and Gardner 1994, Gardner 2013) was an assemblage of three different species that started diversifying during the Mid-Miocene. The analyses uncovered a very old diversification event that resulted in a case of microendemicity, where three morphologically and ecologically similar medium-sized species previously classified within A. caudivolvulus coexist in a very short and narrow mountain stretch.

As a result of this study, two new species – A. gardneri and A. margaritae – were described, both of them widely distributed across the northern tip of the Hajar Mountains. Conversely the third species - Asaccus caudivolvulus sensu stricto - appears to be restricted to a small coastal area of the United Arab Emirates under heavy development, where the only two localities in which the species has ever been recorded occur. The molecular analyses indicate that A. caudivolvulus has been evolving independently from its sister taxon, A. gardneri, for approximately four million years.

In some published literature, this taxon is treated as a subpopulation of the Bourget Whitefish (Coregonus lavaretus) or a member of the "Coregonus lavaretus species complex", and referred to by the English vernacular names "Common Whitefish" or "European Whitefish" (see below).

At the regional scale, the systematics of European ciscoes and whitefishes (Coregonus spp.) has been the subject of considerable debate since the turn of the 21st century, with little indication of a definitive outcome.

It is widely accepted that non-anadromous members of this group have repeatedly undergone adaptive radiations in boreal, subarctic and perialpine lakes (Douglas et al. 1999, Østbye et al. 2005, Kahilainen and Østbye 2006, Harrod et al. 2010, Hudson et al. 2011).

Subpopulations inhabiting these systems largely diversified in the wake of the most recent glacial period 10,000-15,000 years ago. They are typified by parallel patterns of divergence in traits associated with foraging (i.e., gill raker counts, benthic vs. pelagic feeding ecology), physiology (i.e., growth rate, habitat depth partitioning) and reproductive ecology (i.e., reproductive timing and spawning habitat).

Up to six different sympatric forms sometimes referred to as “morphs”, "ecomorphs" or "ecotypes" have been recorded in perialpine lakes, and these radiations might be even more diverse in some large systems of northeastern Europe (Præbel et al. 2013, Doenz et al. 2018, Bitz‐Thorsen et al. 2020, Öhlund et al. 2020).

However, there exist significant differences in opinion regarding the taxonomic status of these forms.

In Northern Europe, including the United Kingdom, all except a handful of Irish subpopulations are usually regarded as belonging to two widely-distributed species; Coregonus albula (ciscoes) and C. lavaretus (whitefishes), with the latter also frequently referred to as the "Coregonus lavaretus species complex” (Etheridge et al. 2012, Wanke et al. 2017, Häkli et al. 2018, Crotti et al. 2020). Within this comparatively uniform taxonomic concept, the catch-all English vernacular name “Vendace” is typically used for C. albula while "Common Whitefish" or "European Whitefish" are applied to C. lavaretus.

Conversely, researchers and fisheries authorities based in Central Europe have tended to treat the different forms as distinct taxa, leading to the recognition of more than 60 species across the European region (Kottelat and Freyhof 2007, Selz et al. 2020, De-Kayne et al. 2022, Selz and Seehausen 2023). Under this diverse taxonomic concept, the name “Vendace” is restricted to its original usage for the United Kingdom endemic Coregonus vandesius and the native range of C. lavaretus is limited to its type locality of Lake Bourget in France.

With the above in mind, it appears unlikely that the striking phenotypic diversity exhibited by members of this genus will ever be adequately represented by a single accepted taxonomic system. In the absence of a region-wide consensus, the IUCN Red List broadly follows the taxonomy provided by Fricke et al. (2024).

The validity of this taxon has been considered questionable in the past, but is unambiguously supported by a range of genetic and morphological evidence (Gigliarelli et al. 2013, Tancioni et al. 2013, Lucentini et al. 2014).

This taxon is currently regarded as valid for global Red List purposes, but was treated as a subpopulation of the Arctic charr, Salvelinus alpinus (Linnaeus 1758), for the most recent national assessment (Nunn et al. 2023).

The taxonomic status of Salvelinus subpopulations inhabiting the British Isles has not been definitively resolved since a series of endemic species were described between the mid-19th and early 20th centuries (Adams and Maitland 2007).

In the United Kingdom and Ireland, all of these taxa are treated as junior synonyms of the congeneric Arctic Charr, Salvelinus alpinus (Linnaeus 1758), the name of which has been routinely applied to a widespread complex of polymorphic charr populations occurring throughout the Holarctic region (Jonsson and Jonsson 2001). However, there remains considerable uncertainty regarding the systematics of the genus across the majority of this range (Reist et al. 2013, Taylor 2016, Whiteley et al. 2019).

Members of this "Arctic Charr complex" exhibit bewildering subpopulation-scale ecological and morphological variability. When such divergence occurs within a single lake system, the different sympatric forms are often referred to as “morphs”, “morphotypes”, "ecomorphs" or "ecotypes" (Snorrason et al. 1994, Adams et al. 1998, Knudsen et al. 2006, Klemetsen 2010, Muir et al. 2016).

Some of these subpopulations and sympatric forms have over time been described as nominal species, including at least 15 from North America, around 30 from Europe and 12 from Siberia and the Far East. However, these taxa encompass only a small fraction of charr distribution and diversity, and there exist significant differences in opinion regarding which of them should be considered valid (Savvaitova 1995, Adams and Maitland 2007, Kottelat and Freyhof 2007, Klemetsen 2010, Whiteley et al. 2019).

With the above in mind, there is an emerging consensus that the striking genetic and phenotypic diversity exhibited by members of this genus cannot be adequately represented by a single accepted taxonomic system (Whiteley et al. 2019).

The Red List currently follows the nomenclature provided by Fricke et al. (2024), albeit a species-oriented conservation management approach is unlikely to prove appropriate for members of this genus (Barthelemy et al. 2023; also see 'Conservation').

Valencia letourneuxi and the congeneric Peloponnese Valencia (Valencia robertae) were considered to represent a single taxon prior to 2014, thus a number of earlier studies and conservation actions refer to both species under the name of the former (Freyhof et al. 2014).
Was under Iguanidae.

This species when described was allocated to the Brachycephalus pernix group (Pie and Ribeiro 2015), a group consisting of 18 formally recognized species (Monteiro et al. 2018). Studies with molecular data confirmed the delimitation of the species (Firkowski et al. 2016). However, Condez et al. (2017) suggest the taxonomic revaluation of B. quiririensis, due to problems in its diagnosis and original description. Pie et al. (2017) refute the arguments and point to the absence of evidence to support a taxonomic reassessment of the species. B. auroguttatus and B. leopardus occur in the same region as B. quirirensis but not in sympatry, their populations are isolated from each other by more than 3 km in Serra do Araçatuba/Serra do Quiriri, a single mountain range located on the border of the states from Paraná and Santa Catarina (Bornschein et al. 2016).

Five endemic Salmo populations from northwest Africa are currently recognised as valid species. All are members of the so-called 'Salmo trutta' (brown trout) complex', which is widely distributed across much of the Palearctic region. However, taxonomic classification within this complex remains a matter of discussion due to its complicated evolutionary history and inherent phenotypic diversity. While a consensus regarding the existence of several distinct phylogeographic lineages (Atlantic, Duero, Mediterranean, Adriatic, Marmoratus, Danubian and Tigris) has been reached, the evolutionary relationships between them remain unclear. In northwest Africa, mitochondrial and nuclear DNA analyses have revealed the existence of three major clades which derived from multiple waves of ancient colonisation; (1) an Afro-Atlantic clade inhabiting Mediterranean coastal rivers of North Africa and the Sous River system in Atlantic Morocco, stemming from a colonisation wave of the Atlantic lineage from Iberia, (2) a relict and native clade inhabiting the Draa River in Atlantic Morocco and (3) a native Atlas Mountains clade which probably arose from a reticulate evolutionary event, following invasion by Atlantic trout that introgressed into local populations.

The drawing of concrete conclusions is complicated, however, because the stocking of hatchery trout appears to have driven significant introgression in some populations. Furthermore, the Salmo trutta complex reaches the southern limit of its natural range in northwest Africa, and most rivers in the region are too warm to support trout populations. Those populations that do exist are mostly confined to high altitude streams and lakes, or perennial headwaters of short Mediterranean rivers. This degree of isolation, coupled with the relatively extreme environmental conditions, has permitted localised adaptation and morphological differentiation which is not necessarily reflected in distinct genetic signatures. In fact, the population inhabiting the Draa River (currently valid as Salmo multipunctatus) constitutes the only case in which a fully preserved indigenous genetic signature has been detected. Additional research employing a broader genomic survey has therefore been recommended to more clearly elucidate the evolutionary and taxonomic relationships between northwest African Salmo populations.

Salmo viridis is included in the Atlas Mountains clade, within which it exhibits a distinct genetic signature. No evidence of artificial stocking has been detected, but it shares genetic affinities with trouts from the Oum Er-Rbia, Tensift (currently valid as Salmo pellegrini), Ziz and Moulouya river systems.

In some published literature, this taxon is referred to as a subpopulation or subspecies of the congeneric Least Cisco (Coregonus albula).

At the regional scale, the systematics of European ciscoes and whitefishes (Coregonus spp.) has been the subject of considerable debate since the turn of the 21st century, with little indication of a definitive outcome.

It is widely accepted that non-anadromous members of this group have repeatedly undergone adaptive radiations in boreal, subarctic and perialpine lakes (Douglas et al. 1999, Østbye et al. 2005, Kahilainen and Østbye 2006, Harrod et al. 2010, Hudson et al. 2011).

Subpopulations inhabiting these systems largely diversified in the wake of the most recent glacial period 10,000-15,000 years ago. They are typified by parallel patterns of divergence in traits associated with foraging (i.e., gill raker counts, benthic vs. pelagic feeding ecology), physiology (i.e., growth rate, habitat depth partitioning) and reproductive ecology (i.e., reproductive timing and spawning habitat).

Up to six different sympatric forms sometimes referred to as “morphs”, "ecomorphs" or "ecotypes" have been recorded in perialpine lakes, and these radiations might be even more diverse in some large systems of northeastern Europe (Præbel et al. 2013, Doenz et al. 2018, Bitz‐Thorsen et al. 2020, Öhlund et al. 2020).

However, there exist significant differences in opinion regarding the taxonomic status of these forms.

In Northern Europe, including the United Kingdom, all except a handful of Irish subpopulations are usually regarded as belonging to two widely-distributed species; Coregonus albula (ciscoes) and C. lavaretus (whitefishes), with the latter also frequently referred to as the "Coregonus lavaretus species complex” (Etheridge et al. 2012, Wanke et al. 2017, Häkli et al. 2018, Crotti et al. 2020). Within this comparatively uniform taxonomic concept, the catch-all English vernacular name “Vendace” is typically used for C. albula while "Common Whitefish" or "European Whitefish" are applied to C. lavaretus.

Conversely, researchers and fisheries authorities based in Central Europe have tended to treat the different forms as distinct taxa, leading to the recognition of more than 60 species across the European region (Kottelat and Freyhof 2007, Selz et al. 2020, De-Kayne et al. 2022, Selz and Seehausen 2023). Under this diverse taxonomic concept, the name “Vendace” is restricted to its original usage for the United Kingdom endemic Coregonus vandesius and the native range of C. lavaretus is limited to its type locality of Lake Bourget in France.

With the above in mind, it appears unlikely that the striking phenotypic diversity exhibited by members of this genus will ever be adequately represented by a single accepted taxonomic system. In the absence of a region-wide consensus, the IUCN Red List broadly follows the taxonomy provided by Fricke et al. (2024).

Otus magicus and O. tempestatis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as O. magicus, and O. alfredi, O. siaoensis, O. enganensis, O. insularis and O. beccarii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were split from O. magicus following Widodo et al. Closely related to C. galerita and C. ophthalmica. Previous recognised taxon included subspecies citrinocristata (del Hoyo & Collar 2014), but this now split as Citron-crested Cockatoo (which see). Subspecies abbotti strikingly large (except in bill size) (3), with small, pale brownish-yellow ear-covert patch (2). Subspecies djampeana and occidentalis generally regarded as synonyms of nominate subspecies and parvula, respectively, but new evaluation indicates real morphological differences and even possible subspecific division within djampeana (Collar & Marsden 2014). Five subspecies recognized.

The taxonomy follows the view of the IWC Scientific Committee and the Society for Marine Mammalogy’s Committee on Taxonomy which now recognize Right Whales in the North Atlantic, North Pacific and Southern Hemisphere as three distinct species in the genus Eubalaena, namely E. glacialis (North Atlantic Right Whale), E. japonica (North Pacific Right Whale), and E. australis (Southern Right Whale) (IWC 2004), based mainly on the mtDNA phylogenetic findings of Rosenbaum et al. (2000).

The North Atlantic Right Whale was included in previous Red Lists together with the North Pacific Right Whale under the species name E. glacialis (Baillie and Groombridge 1996).

Rice (1998) classified Right Whales in the North Atlantic, North Pacific and Southern Hemisphere as the single species Balaena glacialis, in the genus Balaena along with B. mysticetus, the Bowhead Whale. While not all cetologists accept that the three Right Whale taxa qualify as full biological species, their clear geographical separation means that their treatment as separate taxa for conservation purposes is appropriate.

Originally described by Verrill (1868), this species was at one point considered a synonym of M. alcicornis (Boschma 1948) but was subsequently considered as distinct by the same author (Boschma 1962). Millepora nitida is presently considered a valid species based on morphological (Amaral et al. 2008) and genetic evidence (de Souza et al. 2017). Millepora braziliensis is morphologically very similar to its congener, Millepora nitida - differing only in colony morphology, but not in morphometric traits of the skeleton (Verrill 1868, de Souza et al. 2017).

Originally described by Verrill (1868), Millepora braziliensis is considered a valid species based on morphological (Amaral 2008) and genetic evidence (de Souza et al. 2017). This species is morphologically very similar to its congener, Millepora nitida - differing only in colony morphology, but not in morphometric traits of the skeleton (Verrill 1868, de Souza et al. 2017).

This taxon was formerly considered a subspecies of N. concolor, however, the light-cheeked gibbons were subsequently separated (Dao Van Tien 1983; Ma and Wang 1986; Ma et al. 1988) and then further divided into the four taxa currently recognized with the separation of N. gabriellae (Groves 1993), then N. siki (e.g. Groves 2001; Mootnick 2006; Geissmann 2007; Van Ngoc Thinh et al. 2010a; Van Ngoc Thinh et al. 2010b; Mootnick and Fan Pengfei 2011; Van Ngoc Thinh et al. 2011) and finally with the recent description of N. annamensis (Van Ngoc Thin et al. 2010c). Nomascus leucogenys was previously considered to overlap with N. concolor in Viet Nam and Yunnan, China (Dao Van Tien 1983; Ma and Wang 1986), however, there seems to be insufficient evidence to currently conclude this (Fooden 1996; Geissmann et al. 2000; Rawson et al. 2011).
Coracornis sanghirensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Colluricincla sanghirensis.

Amazona autumnalis, A. diadema and A. lilacina (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as A. autumnalis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Cytogenetic and molecular data do not distinguish Hapalemur alatorensis from H. griseus griseus (Fausser et al. 2002, Pastorini et al. 2002), although the former is differentiated based on its larger size (Rabarivola et al. 2007).
Gracula religiosa, G. venerata, G. robusta and G. indica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as G. religiosa following AOU (1998 and supplements) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
The common name for this species in Vietnamese is Rùa Trung Bộ.

Previously lumped as C. banyumas with C. whitei and C. montanus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016), but those species now split following Eaton et al. (2016) and specimen examination. Differs from C. whitei by its broad black chin vs narrow or none in male (1); continuously russet underparts vs only throat/breast (belly/vent whitish) in both sexes (3); markedly greyer vs olive-brown upperparts in female (2); greater wing length (unmeasured, but at least 1); evidently different voice (Gwee et al. 2019) (not assessed, but at least 1). For differences from C. montanus, see that species. Has been considered conspecific with C. lemprieri; songs rather similar, and separation based mainly on plumage. Until recently considered conspecific with C. magnirostris, which proves to be vocally rather close to present species. Subspecies mardii, described from Panaitan I, off Java, sometimes recognised. Two subspecies recognised.

This is a split from the broader concept of Pristimantis phoxocephalus (Páez and Ron 2019). Pristimantis teslai has been mistakenly identified as P. phoxocephalus (e.g., collections at the QCAZ museum). This species could be a synonym of P. modipeplus (M. Yánez-Muñoz pers. comm. 2021).

Vieira (1944) recognized two subspecies of Brachyteles. Recent evidence provided by Lemos de Sá et al. (1990), Fonseca et al. (1991) and Lemos de Sá and Glander (1993) indicated that Vieira’s original (1944) standing was valid, but that differentiation is even more extreme and justifies the classification of the two forms as separate species (see also Coimbra-Filho et al. 1993). Groves (2001, 2005) lists the two muriquis as separate species.

Vieira (1944) recognized two subspecies of Brachyteles. Recent evidence provided by Lemos de Sá et al. (1990), Fonseca et al. (1991) and Lemos de Sá and Glander (1993) indicated that Vieira’s original (1944) standing was valid, but that differentiation is even more extreme and justifies the classification of the two forms as separate species (see also Coimbra-Filho et al. 1993). Groves (2001, 2005) lists the two muriquis as separate species.

In the past, the eastern Brazilian marmosets (penicillata É. Geoffroy, 1812, geoffroyi É. Geoffroy in Humboldt, 1812, aurita É. Geoffroy in Humboldt, 1812, and flaviceps Thomas, 1903) of the “jacchus group” were considered to be subspecies of Callithrix jacchus, following Hershkovitz (1977). All are now considered to be full species (see Coimbra-Filho and Mittermeier 1973, Coimbra-Filho 1984, Mittermeier et al. 1988, Mendes 1997b, Marroig et al. 2004, Coimbra-Filho et al. 2006).

Coimbra-Filho (1986a,b, 1990) and Coimbra-Filho et al. (1993b) argued that Callithrix flaviceps should be considered a subspecies of C. aurita. The similarities between C. flaviceps and C. aurita in pelage patterns such as the ear tufts and the skull-like facial mask, ecological adaptations, ontogeny (the infants are extremely similar), vocalizations and clinal variation in overall pelage colour, based this opinion (Coimbra-Filho 1986a,b; Coimbra-Filho et al. 1993). However, Ferrari et al. (1996) rejected the subspecies status of C. flaviceps based on ecological and behavioural studies of groups of C. flaviceps and C. aurita. Rylands (2012) corroborates this view and considers C. flaviceps as a full species.

To date there have been only preliminary and non-conclusive molecular genetic assessments of Cebus aequatorialis (Boubli et al. 2012; Ruiz-García et al. 2010, 2018), and so its provisional status as a species is based on its geographic isolation from other Cebus albifrons populations and its unique morphological characteristics such as pelage colouration. Jack and Campos (2012) suggest elevating C. aequatorialis to species level following the phylogenetic species concept. Albuja et al. (2018) provide a preliminary cranio-dental and morphological analysis showing differences between Cebus aequatorialis and another Ecuadorian capuchin species, Cebus yuracus; however, their sample size is too small to be conclusive in terms of species distinction.

Described by Hershkovitz (1988, 1990) as a subspecies of Callicebus personatus. Kobayashi and Langguth (1999) argued that the titis of the Atlantic forest should be considered species rather than subspecies of C. personatus. They listed C. nigrifrons, C. personatus, C. melanochir and C. coimbrai besides C. barbarabrownae. According to Printes (2007), the name Callicebus barbarabrownae (Hershkovitz, 1990), may prove to be a junior synonym of Callicebus gigot (Spix, 1823), according to the principle of priority.

Cebus kaapori was originally described by Queiroz in 1992, as who pointed out its resemblance with Cebus olivaceus. It had been previously recorded from Pará and Maranhão (Goeldi and Hagmann 1906 apud Silva Jr. 2001, Vieira 1957) as Cebus nigrivittatus and overlooked in subsequent assessments of the range of the species. Harada and Ferrari (1996), based on genetic data, argued that Cebus kaapori should be considered as a subspecies of C. olivaceus. However, Cebus kaapori was considered a valid species by Groves (2001, 2005) and Silva Jr. (2001) in regard of morphological evidence. Later on, new molecular evidence (Alfaro et al. 2012a,b) supported the current understanding that it is a valid species, and this is the current prevailing systematic arrangement (Paglia et al. 2012).

The most detailed taxonomic treatment for this species remains that of Fooden (1963) who placed it in the genus Lagothrix. However, as a result of his comparative studies of cranial morphology in the atelines, Groves (2001, 2005) and Paredes (2003) concluded that the Peruvian Yellow-tailed Woolly Monkey should properly be considered a monotypic genus, Oreonax Thomas, 1927, quite separate from the woolly monkeys. More recent genetic studies by Di Fiore et al. (2014) and Ruiz Garcia et al. (2014) provide support for its position within the genus Lagothrix.

Orr and Hämäläinen (2007: 66) note that two forms of this species exist, differing in size, and that "Further field studies are required to clarify the biological status of these two possibly seasonal forms."

Byrne et al. (2016) split the genus Callicebus into three new genera, namely:  Cheracebus (torquatus-group sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002), Plecturocebus (cupreus-, moloch-, donacophilus-groups sensu Roosmalen et al. (2002) and Callicebus (personatus-group, sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002). According to Byrne et al. (2016), Plecturocebus includes 22 species.

Hershkovitz (1977) considered Saguinus geoffroyi to be a subspecies of S. oedipus. Comparative morphological studies by Hanihara and Natori (1987), Moore and Cheverud (1992) and Skinner (1991) argued for them being separate species. Eisenberg (1989), Rylands (1993), Hernández-Camacho and Cooper (1976), Mittermeier and Coimbra-Filho (1981), Hernández-Camacho and Defler (1989), Mittermeier et al. (1988), Rylands et al. (1993), Groves (1993, 2001, 2005), Mast et al. (1993) and Defler (1994) all list S. geoffroyi and S. oedipus as separate species.

Hershkovitz (1977) considered Saguinus bicolor to have three subspecies: the nominate, S. b. ochraceus and S. b. martinsi. Groves (2001, 2005) and Rylands et al. (1993, 2000) listed the forms ochraceus and martinsi as subspecies of S. martinsi.

Silva Jr (2001, 2002) argued that the tufted capuchins and the untufted capuchins (sensu Hershkovitz 1949, 1955) are so distinct in their morphology that they should be considered separate genera. Cebus Erxleben, 1777 for the untufted group, and Sapajus Kerr, 1792 is the name available for the tufted capuchins.

With a unique karyotype (Seuánez et al. 1986) and evidence for relatively early divergence from other Sapajus species (Lynch Alfaro et al. 2012; Nascimento et al. 2015), Sapajus xanthosternos is considered a distinct species based on morphological characteristics by both Groves (2001, 2005) and Silva Jr. (2001).
