The original Latin species name (ahmansoni) stems from the naming of the species after a man, Robert Ahmanson. The species has occasionally been incorrectly referred to as ahmansonorum (e.g. Hoffmann et al. 2009) and ahmansorum but the species should be referred to using the original Latin name.

Tattersall (2007) has cautioned that the Lepilemur species reported by Louis et al. 2006 (that were diagnosed exclusively on genetic distance and all allopatric) be treated with extreme caution until supporting data are forthcoming. However, Lei et al. (2016) subsequently established through delimitation analyses of mitogenomic data, that this species is valid despite allopatry.

There are several localities in Mozambique (Mt. Namuli, Mt. Mabu) which were originally suspected to contain populations of Rhampholeon chapmanorum (Tilbury 2010). However, molecular phylogenetic analysis confirms that R. chapmanorum is endemic to remaining forest fragments on Malawi Hill, and the Mozambican localities are home to separate species of Rhampholeon (Branch et al. 2014).
No outstanding taxonomic issues.

The genus Pycnopodia is monophyletic, and Pycnopodia helianthoides is the only species in the genus. Pycnopodia helianthoides is one of only two species in the sub-family Pycnopodiinae, the other is Lysastrosoma anthosticta from Japan (Accessed through: WoRMS, World Register of Marine Species at: http://www.marinespecies.org/aphia.php?p=taxdetails&id=240764 on 2020-08-04).
This species was elevated to species status by La Marca (1983).

This species is recovered in various places throughout the dendrobatine phylogeny, either as sister to the genus Adelphobates or to all other dendrobatines aside from Phyllobates and C. ruthveni (see Frost 2020 for a complete review of the systematic of this taxon). Currently, Minyobates is a monotypic genus, but additional phylogenetic research is needed (La Marca 2016).

Originally described as Prostherapis neblina by Test (1956) and subsequently transferred to Colostethus by Edwards (1971) and to Mannophryne by La Marca (1992). Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne, has been recently corroborated by Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Previous to Grant et al. (2006) the genus Aromobates was known only by a single species: A. nocturnus (Myers et al. 1991). Then, Grant et al. (2006) moved all Colostethus of the alboguttatus group (sensu Rivero 1988) or Nephelobates (sensu La Marca 1994) to Aromobates and provided a well-corroborated phylogeny of the genus. Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012) provide a phylogeny and a list with current threats for all species of the genus. Rivero (1982a) included Colostehus inflexus Rivero, 1978 in the synonymy of C. alboguttatus. Myers, Paolillo and Daly (1991) and La Marca (1997) revive the species as Nephelobates inflexus in their works without explanation. Recently, Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012) consider inflexus different from A. alboguttatus and a valid species, but without supporting evidence.

Originally described under the genus Colostethus by Dole and Durant (1972). It was transferred to Nephelobates by La Marca (1994) and lastly reallocated to Aromobates by Grant et al. (2006). Its phylogenetic position (as part of Aromobates) has been corroborated by Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012), Grant et al. (2017), and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012) suggested that the type material of Aromobates orostoma requires additional examination to confirm its status, and its relationship with A. inflexus should be evaluated.

In the Pristimantis (Pristimantis) unistrigatus species group by Hedges et al. (2008). This species has not been included in any phylogenetic study, and has not been assigned to any species group in the last molecular analysis of the New World direct-developing frogs of Padial et al. (2014). In the family Strabomantidae sensu Heinicke et al. (2018).

Originally described as a member of Eleutherodactylus (Walker and Test 1955) and later transferred to Pristimantis (Heinicke et al. 2007). Hedges et al. (2008) and Padial et al. (2014) also listed this species as part of Pristimantis but did not assign it to any species group as it was not included in their phylogenetic analyses. Its evolutionary relationships remain unknown.

La Marca (2007) erected the genus Mucubatrachus to accommodate species that have a dermal fold posterior to the urostyle and before the cloaca. Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis. Pristimantis thyellus can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters and colour patterns (La Marca 2007).

This species was originally described as Colostethus caribe, but a year later was moved to the genus Allobates based on its morphological characteristics (Lötters et al. 2007).

Lötters et al. (2007: 60) in an apparent transcription mistake made reference to this species as Anomaloglossus caribe.

Since its description (Barrio-Amorós and Santos 2012) it has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its taxonomic position has been corroborated in two recent phylogenetic studies (Grant et al. 2017, Rojas-Runjaic 2019).

Pristimantis phoxocephalus was formerly considered a single highly polymorphic species (e.g., Lynch 1979, Lynch and Duellman 1997, Duellman and Lehr 2009). Páez and Ron (2019) showed that most subpopulations previously ascribed to P. phoxocephalus represent other species (e.g., Pristimantis atillo, P. jimenezi, P. teslai sp. nov., P. torresi sp. nov., P. totoroi sp. nov., P. verrucolatus sp. nov., Pristimantis sp. (CCS2), Pristimantis sp. (UCS2), Pristimantis sp. (UCS3)). This is the new narrower concept of Pristimantis phoxocephalus.
Rheinardia nigrescens formerly regarded as a subspecies of this species but is split following Davison et al. (2020). Monotypic.

authority: Patton, Apodaca, Corser, Wilson, Williams, Cameron & Wake, 2019
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Aneides aeneus (Patton et al. 2019).

Blue-throated Hillstar, described by Sornoza-Molina et al. (2018), is accepted as a species diagnosable and scorable against O. stolzmanni on the Tobias criteria by its blue vs green throat in male (4); greener, brighter upperparts in male (1); dark greyish vs whitish base colour to chin and throat in female [see Sornoza-Molina et al. (2018) Appendix Figure 11] (1); slightly smaller size, albeit sample sizes are small (1). Monotypic.

Previously considered a subspecies of C. sulphurea. Collar & Marsden (2014) used the Tobias criteria to evaluate the taxonomic status of the subspecies citrinocristata from Sumba of the Yellow-crested Cockatoo Cacatua sulphurea. They found that it met the criteria (scoring 7) against every other taxon except C. s. parvula, against which it scored only 6 as a result of the latter’s surprisingly long tail (by comparison with other Wallacean yellow-crests). This may have been a case of an overly strict application of the criteria, and the decision was ignored by Eaton et al. (2016) who readily split the ‘Sumba Cockatoo’. With the further disclosure that fledgling citrinocristata have black bills and fledgling sulphurea of all known forms have pale bills, we have further evidence of a distinction between Sumba birds and the others, we reverse the decision in Collar & Marsden (2014) to keep citrinocristata lumped and now regard it as a full species. Monotypic.

Several taxonomic experts suspect that the species as it exists now is not valid. Should the invalidity of the existing species be published, this species assessment should be invalidated. Additional taxonomic research should be undertaken to verify, and is included as a research recommendation within the assessment.
Records of this species off Argentina refer to Mustelus schmitti.

Three elephant taxa remain from the sixteen elephant-like species that are known from across the planet in the Pleistocene: Asian Elephant (Elephas maximus), African Savanna Elephant (Loxodonta africana), and African Forest Elephant (Loxodonta cyclotis) (Faurby and Svenning 2015, Malhi et al. 2016). The Asian and African ancestral lineages diverged approximately seven million years ago, and the African Savanna and African Forest ancestral lineages began diverging approximately one million years later (Rohland et al. 2010, Brandt et al. 2014, Roca et al. 2015, Meyer et al. 2017, Palkopoulou et al. 2018). The Third Edition of ‘Mammal Species of the World’ (Wilson and Reeder 2005) was the first to formally designate the African elephant as these two separate species. Recent genetic findings also support this designation (Roca et al. 2007, Ishida et al. 2011, Mondol et al. 2015, Palkopoulou et al. 2018, Kim and Wasser 2019). Hybridization between the two species appears restricted and evident at only 14 of the more than 100 localities recently examined across the vast forest-savanna ecotone. In nine of these 14 localities, hybrid individuals occurred alongside non-hybrid individuals of either one species or the other and not both (i.e., three localities had hybrids and African Forest Elephants only and assigned as this species; six localities had hybrids and African Savanna Elephants only and assigned as this species). For the IUCN Red List assessments, a distribution map published in Mondol et al. (2015) and recent data by Kim and Wasser (2019) are used to assign localities as range of either L. africana or L. cyclotis.

authority: Neira-Salamea, Ofori-Boateng, Kouamé, Blackburn, Segniagbeto, Hillers, Barej, Leaché & Rödel, 2021

taxonomicNotes: Gyps rueppelli (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as G. rueppellii.
Proposed subspecies pileatus differs only in size, which varies clinally, increasing from small in W to large in E and S; no longer recognised (Barlow et al. 2020). Monotypic.

Presbytis percura was described by M.W. Lyon, Jr. in 1908 based on specimens collected from near Siak Kecil River, Makapan, Kompei, Pulau Rupat, and Salat Rupat (Lyon 1908). It was later regarded as a subspecies of P. femoralis, along with P. f. femoralis and P. f. robinsoni (Groves 2001, Meyer et al. 2011, Groves and Roos 2013, Roos et al. 2014). However, genetic data suggested that at least P. f. femoralis and P. f. robinsoni were different species (Ang 2010, Nijman 2019) which was also in agreement with their morphological characters.

Resolving all subspecies-level boundaries within banded langurs required data for P. f. percura, which was the least studied among the three taxa and only found in the Riau Province in Sumatra (Rizaldi et al. 2019). Complete mitochondrial genomes were later obtained for P. f. percura in the wild, and based on multiple species delimitation algorithms (PTP, ABGD, Objective Clustering) applied to a dataset covering 40 species and 43 subspecies of Asian colobines, all three subspecies of banded langurs were resurrected to species (Ang et al. 2020).

Presbytis percura is mainly blackish above, with a grey head and a white underside (Lyon 1908, Aimi and Bakar 1992). White underside is narrow but extends horizontally across chest, down inner sides of limbs in thin stripes to wrists and ankles, and to cheeks and chin. The tail is black and not bicolour, but part of the ventral surface of the basal third of the tail is indistinctly white. Its throat and face are grey, and there are narrow, pale eye-rings. One (sometimes two) whorls are set well back on its crown. Hairs on the chest are directed backward.

The foetuses are white with a black stripe from the head to the tail, intersected by another black stripe along the outer surfaces of both forearms, forming a distinctive cruciform (cross-like) black pattern on the dorsum.

This taxon was considered a subspecies of Nycticebus coucang but elevated by Groves and Maryanto (2008). This is further supported by morphological studies by Nekaris and Jaffe (2007) and Nekaris and Munds (2010) and genetic studies by Roos (2003) and Wirdateti et al. (2006). Two distinct forms regularly occur in bird markets and further research is needed (Nekaris and Jaffe 2007). Care should be taken in taxonomic studies however due to translocation of individuals from markets into forests and gardens throughout the island (Schulze and Groves 2004). The distinct black and white long-haired appearance of subadults and juveniles also might be mistaken as separate species, for example, in museum specimens or from photos only (KA. Nekaris et al. pers. comm. 2012).

Recent changes to the systematics of Rhinobatos have elevated the subgenus Glaucostegus to full generic status and placed this genus into a family of its own: Glaucostegidae (Compagno 2005, Last et al. 2016a). Reports of G. obtusus from South Africa are considered invalid and based on other species (Compagno and Last 1999).
Lophura erythrophthalma and L. pyronota (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as L. erythrophthalma following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Recent changes to the systematics of Rhinobatos have elevated the subgenus Glaucostegus to full generic status and placed this genus into a family of its own: Glaucostegidae (Compagno 2005, Last et al. 2016a).

Rice’s Whale (Balaenoptera ricei) is a distinct evolutionary lineage closely related to Eden’s Whale (Balaenoptera edeni edeni), Bryde’s Whale (B. e. brydei) and Sei Whale (Balaenoptera borealis) (Rosel et al. 2021). Previously considered an undescribed subspecies of Balaenoptera edeni and referred to as the Gulf of Mexico Whale or the Gulf of Mexico Bryde’s Whale, a recent morphological study of Rice’s Whale has revealed diagnostic differences in the shape and size of bones in the skull in comparison to the two subspecies of B. edeni. This morphological evidence reinforced earlier findings of significant genetic divergence and fixed DNA differences found in several mitochondrial DNA genes; together, these data supported the description of the new species B. ricei. With elevation of Rice’s Whale to species status, there is still uncertainty as to whether Eden’s Whale and Bryde’s Whale, each of which is clearly distinct, represent subspecies of B. edeni or full species.

Until rather recently this species was regarded as subspecies of Pyrrhosoma nymphula. Kalkman and Lopau (2006) illustrated the differences between the two taxa and confirmed that they should be treated as two full valid species, which is the widely accepted taxonomic rank now.

authority: Chaves-Portilla, Salazar, Gil-Acero, Dorado-Correa, Márquez, Rueda-Almonacid & Amézquita, 2021

taxonomicNotes: Bradypus pygmaeus has only recently been described by Anderson and Handley (2001) as a separate species.

Zanda baudinii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Calyptorhynchus. Original note from Illustrated Checklists: Closely related to Z. funerea and Z. latirostris. Long considered conspecific with latter, but currently treated as separate species because ecology quite different, and bill significantly longer; difficulty in field identification, compounded by long history of conspecific treatment, has led to uncertainty regarding limits of range in area of overlap, and to publication of some inaccurate maps. Present species has also, on occasion, been lumped in Z. funerea. Confusion over bill size of specimen used in original description led to proposal of subspecies tenuirostris, but this name shown to be synonymous with baudinii (Schodde and Mason 1997). Monotypic.
Identified as a new species by genetic analyses, this species combines morphological features of both P. austriacus and P. auritus.

Here we refer to P. teneriffae as the population of the Canary Islands. Northwest African populations previously assigned to P. teneriffae are currently included in P. gaisleri, and Balkan populations are assigned to P. austriacus. The taxonomic status of the species was confirmed by Spitzenberger et al. (2006). There are no significant genetic differences between populations on the islands of the Canary Archipelago where this species is found (Juste et al. 2004).

The taxon is often considered as a subspecies of the Asian Pseudochazara hippolyte. However, the type species of P. hippolyte was described from the Ural Mountains and showed clear morphological differences from Iberian specimens described by Romei in 1927 (Olivares et al. 2011). Subsequently, Kudrna et al. (2011, 2015) and Wiemers et al. (2018) accepted full species status of P. williamsi.
There are no taxonomic concerns with relevance to the validity of the species and no taxonomic revisions underway.

Differences in morphological, ecological and behavioural traits suggest that the current five-species arrangement does not accurately reflect species diversity within Kosciuscola (Tatarnic et al. 2013, Umbers et al. 2021). Molecular work has identified species-level clades within K. tristis (Umbers et al. 2021), and provided strong evidence supporting the elevation of K. tristis restrictus to species level as K. restrictus (Song et al. 2021).

The species has been previously identified as Ctenodesma borneensis (Zieritz et al. 2020). However, molecular phylogenetic analysis revealed that Khairuloconcha is a divergent lineage sister to C. borneensis and can morphologically be discriminated from C. borneensis by its sharper posterior ridge with nodulous sculpturing (especially dorsally) and a faint zigzag or irregular sculpture on the posterior slope rather than uniform plications (Zieritz et al. 2021).

The species has been previously identified as Ctenodesma borneensis (lot FMNH 116932 [FMNH = Field Museum of Natural History, Chicago, USA]). However, molecular phylogenetic analysis revealed that Khairuloconcha is a divergent lineage sister to C. borneensis and can morphologically be discriminated from C. borneensis by its sharper posterior ridge with nodulous sculpturing (especially dorsally) and a faint zigzag or irregular sculpture on the posterior slope rather than uniform plications (Zieritz et al. in 2021).

Based on morphological observations, Zlatarski and Estalella (1982), Bouchon and Laborel (1986) and Fenner (1993) concluded that Colpophyllia breviserialis should not be treated as a valid species separate from C. natans but it is considered valid according to Reyes et al. (2010) and the WoRMS online database (accessed February 2022). According to Spathias (2017), a taxonomic revision of the Colpophyllia genus that is underway is intended to resolve the uncertain status of C. breviserialis.

The species was originally described as Helix pittae by Paiva in 1866, and not as Helix (Discula) polymorpha var. δ pittae as stated in Wollaston (1878) (refer to Actinella fecundaerrata in Teixeira et al. 2019). In Bank et al. (2002), it was referred to as Caseolus (Caseolus?) innominatus pittae, but the basis of record was amended to Caseolus (Caseolus?) pittae (Paiva, 1866) in Teixeira et al. (2019) where lectotypes where designated. That nomenclature was then followed in Cameron et al. (2021).

This species was recently described by Habib and Islam (2021). It is similar to, and sympatric with, Glaucostegus granulatus in Bangladesh, but the description of the new species does not change the taxonomic concept of G. granulatus.

Genetic (Rosel et al. 1995) and morphological (Brownell et al. 1987) data suggest that Vaquitas are most closely related to porpoises in South America. Genetic data suggest divergence from two sister taxa (Burmeister’s Porpoise, Phocoena spinipinnis and Spectacled Porpoise Australophocaena dioptrica) in the Pleistocene (i.e., at least 2.5 million years ago).
Microcebus berthae is the name given to the diminutive Rufous-colored Mouse Lemur from Kirindy/CFPF, originally called M. myoxinus by Schmid and Kappeler (1994).

Presbytis femoralis formerly was regarded as a subspecies of P. melalophos (Thorington and Groves 1970, Medway 1983, Napier 1985, Oates et al. 1994), but later was recognized as a species with three subspecies: P. f. femoralis, P. f. percura and P. f. robinsoni (Groves 2001, Meyer et al. 2011, Groves and Roos 2013, Roos et al. 2014).

Genetic data suggested that at least P. f. femoralis and P. f. robinsoni were different species (Ang 2010, Nijman 2019), which also agreed with their morphological characters. However, resolving all subspecies-level boundaries within banded langurs required data for P. f. percura, which was the least studied and only found in the Riau Province in Sumatra (Rizaldi et al. 2019). Complete mitochondrial genomes were later obtained for P. f. percura in the wild, and based on multiple species delimitation algorithms (PTP, ABGD, Objective Clustering) applied to a dataset covering 40 species and 43 subspecies of Asian colobines, all three subspecies of banded langurs were resurrected to species (Ang et al. 2020).

Presbytis femoralis was described by Martin (1838) based on specimens collected by Raffles (1821) from Singapore. However, Martin (1838) gave the distribution as "Sumatra etc.", not mentioning Singapore explicitly, resulting in some confusion over the actual type locality (Miller 1934, Low and Lim 2015). Miller (1934) determined Singapore as the actual type locality, and the secretariat of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature confirmed the authorship of P. femoralis as Martin, the year of publication as 1838, and the type locality as Singapore (Low and Lim 2015).

Presbytis femoralis is uniform black on the dorsum with a white band traversing down the chest and abdomen, the inside of the humeri from the axilla, and the inside of the thighs (Raffles 1821, Martin 1838, Groves 2001). In contrast to the adult pelage, infants are born with a white coat with a broad black band from the head, along the spine, to the tail, and intersected by a black band passing along the shoulders to the outer surfaces of both forearms, forming a distinctive cruciform (cross-like) black pattern on the dorsum. A faint black line runs from the dark spinal stripe along the hind legs to the feet. The crown and facial hair are completely white from the frontal view. The forehead is slightly dark compared to the pale colour of the face (Pocock 1928, Ang et al. 2010).

authority: López-Luna, Cupul-Magaña, Escobedo-Galván, González-Hernández, Centenero-Alcalá, Rangel-Mendoza, Ramírez-Ramírez & Cazares-Hernández, 2018
taxonomicNotes: López-Luna et al. (2018, 2021) described and characterized this range-restricted mud turtle (Kinosternon vogti) from the coastal Bahía de Banderas region of Jalisco, Mexico. Based on morphologic and genetic analysis it is most closely related to K. cora, K. chimalhuaca and K. hirtipes.
This group was revised in Mordan and Frias Martins (2001).
Rhinopithecus brelichi was formerly considered a subspecies of Rhinopithecus roxellana, but is now accepted as specifically distinct (Groves 2001).

Unio tumidiformis was considered by Haas (1969) to be a junior synonym of Unio crassus and to belong to the subspecies Unio crassus batavus, which joined the French and Iberian populations of Unio crassus. It was considered a junior synonym of Unio crassus until the end of the 20th century. Since then, the taxonomy of the Iberian populations of Unio crassus has been revised based on molecular, morphological and reproductive characters, showing that they are well differentiated from those of northern and central Europe (Reis and Araujo 2009). Therefore, the Iberian populations of Unio crassus were included in a species redescribed as Unio tumidiformis, a valid and separate species from Unio crassus (Reis and Araujo 2009).

Changes to the systematics of Rhinobatos elevated the subgenus Glaucostegus to full generic status and placed this genus into a family of its own: Glaucostegidae (Compagno 2005, Last et al. 2016a). This species is often confused with Glaucostegus typus and Pacific Ocean records of G. granulatus are probably G. typus. A newly-described species, Glaucostegus younholeei Habib & Islam, 2021, is sympatric with G. granulatus in Bangladesh but the description of the new species does not change the taxonomic concept of G. granulatus.

A second species of Hypogeomys is known from the subfossil record. Hypogeomys australis was still extant 4,400 years ago, and once occurred from southeastern Madagascar north to at least the Antsirabe region (Goodman and Rakotondravony 1996).
Otidiphaps nobilis, O. aruensis, O. cervicalis and O. insularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as O. nobilis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

authority: Simmons, Flanders, Fils, Parker, Suter, Bamba, Douno, Keita, Morales, & Frick, 2021
taxonomicNotes: Species first described in 2021 after two individuals were caught in the Nimba Mountains in January 2018 as part of a biodiversity assessment. While Myotis nimbaensis shares similar features with three other large Myotis (subgenus Chrysopteron) species with orange dorsal fur occur in Africa (M. tricolor, M. welwitschii, and M. morrisi), it is easily distinguishable due to its body size and various color patterns (Simmons et al. 2021).

Synonym = Testudo leithii Günther, 1869 (non Testudo leithii Carter, 1852)). The species was classified into the subgenus Pseudotestudo by Loveridge and Williams (1957). This subgeneric name is nonapplicable for T. kleinmanni because the taxon was based on juvenile characters not retained into adulthood (Bour 1989).

The species' assessment change between 2007 and 2022 was the result of (i) systematic work: the species was previously published as Hydrobia marocana (Pallary 1921) and was reported from four localities two of them were in Algeria (Ghamizi 1998). Boulaassafer et al. 2021 reported recent systematic findings which led to assigning the species to the genus Corrosella (), since the genus is very restricted to freshwater springs, it is highly endemic and unlikely to be the same species in Algeria. Boulaassafer et al. 2021 restrict the presence of C. marocana in Morocco. The species is now restricted to ditches and irrigation canals where individuals were found in very low abundance attached to stones or dead branches.

The Chinese Sturgeon Acipenser sinensis is restricted to the main channel of the Yangtze and the Pearl rivers and the East and South China Seas. Though there is still disagreement about the taxonomy of the Pearl and Yangtze River populations, Chinese scholars commonly divide Chinese Sturgeon into two populations; one is the Pearl River Chinese Sturgeon, which spawns in spring, and is close to dying out. The other is the Yangtze River Chinese Sturgeon, which spawns in autumn and still maintains a certain amount below the Gezhouba Dam.
The family Vitrinidae in the Canary Islands was treated by Valido et al. (1999).
The genus Obelus was revised by Ibáñez et al. (2003).

Seddon (2008) reported that Wollaston (1878) and Waldén (1983) noted that var. subdubia is apparently intermediate between L. wollastoni and L. nivosa; both authors nonetheless treated wollastoni as a distinct species. The intermediate is only found in a very small area on Pico do Concelho, whereas in most parts of their ranges, the two species are clearly and distinctly separable. The subfossil shells from the Quaternary deposits below Pico do Concelho are larger than the living shells.

Mandahl-Barth (1950) treated the population of Ilheu de Fora off the eastern coast as a distinct subspecies. MolluscaBase (2025) recognises two subspecies, Leptaxis wollastoni ssp. forensis (Wollaston, 1878) and Leptaxis wollastoni ssp. wollastoni (R.T. Lowe, 1852)

This species was previously assessed under the name Leiostyla laevigata. Bank et al. (2002) proposed Leiostyla falknerorum nom. nov. as a new name for Pupa laevigata Lowe, 1852 as they considered it to be preoccupied by Pupa laevigata von Gallenstein, 1848. This name was known to Pilsbry (1922-26) and Waldén (1983), who both considered it a forgotten name.

This species was previously included within Pristurus rupestris, but was found to be a separate species, with its description in preparation (S. Carranza pers. comm. September 2022). The species is sympatric with P. rupestris.

This species seems closely related to Samoana conica, but its shells are dextral, whereas those of S. conica are sinistral. Its shell is generally yellowish-green in colour. It is the least common of the three Tutuila partulids.
Formerly considered as a subspecies of Sicista subtilis, but now recognized as a separate species based on caryotype and DNA data (Kovalskaya et al. 2011, Lebedev et al. 2020).

There are two chromosome races of this species: Spermophilus suslicus odessanus (36 chromosomes) and Spermophilus suslicus sensu stricto (34 chromosomes). These are separated by the Dnieper River. Sometimes considered as separate species, genetic and acoustic data support the integrity of both races into one species (Matrosova et al. 2016).

The taxonomic status of Ammobates handlirschi (Friese, 1895), a close north African relative to A. dusmeti, needs to be confirmed by more comprehensive study, especially by methods of population biology based on DNA.

This species was described in 2017, based on a reanalysis of material from the type locality. The species from this location was originally identified as the Sardinian species Mercuria zopissa in Falkner et al. (2002), and occupies a habitat that has changed since first collection and hence population was considered to be declining and maybe now be extinct (Boeters and Falkner 2017).

authority: G.A. Holyoak, D.T. Holyoak & da Costa Mendes, 2017

taxonomicNotes:
Considering molecular, morphological and biogeographic evidence, Byrne et al. (2016) proposed new genus-level systematics for the former arrangement of Callicebus species from Hershkovitz (1990): Cheracebus Byrne et al. 2016 genus for the species in the Orinoco, Negro and upper Amazon basins; Callicebus Thomas, 1903 genus for the species in the Atlantic Forest; and Plecturocebus Byrne et al. 2016 genus for the species in the Amazon basin and Chaco.

Plecturocebus vieirai was described in 2012 from three localities in Pará State, Brazil (type locality: Renato River, a tributary of the right bank of the Teles Pires river, near the city of Cláudia, Mato Grosso; 11° 33' 00.15" S, 55° 10' 59.98" W) (Gualda-Barros et al. 2012), in an area formerly attributed to P. moloch sensu Hershkovitz (1990). The Vieira’s titi monkey is currently known to occur west of the Xingu River, east of the Iriri and Teles Pires rivers, southward to the headwaters of the Xingu and Teles Pires rivers, until the border between Amazonia–Cerrado biomes (Costa-Araújo et al. in press), and it is sister taxon to P. moloch (Boubli et al. 2019).

authority: Lanza, Leo, Forti, Cimmaruta, Caputo & Nascetti, 2001
taxonomicNotes: Lanza et al. (2001) described this taxon as a subspecies of Speleomantes imperialis, but it was elevated to species status by Carranza et al. (2007).
The taxonomic status of the species has only recently been clarified. Previously, it was considered conspecific with North American Green Sturgeon (A. medirostris) (Shmigirilov et al. 2007).
This is the only representative of its genus.

This new species was described by Melo et al. (2022). It differs from congeners most conspicuously in its distinctive call, which is most similar to that of the widely allopatric O. ireneae. Monotypic.

As part of a revision of the species complex then referred to as "Tympanocryptis pinguicolla", Melville et al. (2019) made the unexpected finding that the lectotype of Tympanocryptis lineata (assigned by Wells and Wellington 1985) was applicable to a member of the T. pinguicolla complex, and that its universal association with a striped earless dragon was in error.

These authors' work identified four species-level lineages within the group they consequently referred to "temperate grassland earless dragon group", and that the names T. lineata and T. pinguicolla referred to distinct species. The remaining two populations were described as the new species T. osbornei and T. mccartneyi.

The name Tympanocryptis pinguicolla was previously used to describe the greater grassland earless dragon complex across New South Wales, the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) and Victoria (Robertson and Evans 2012), and briefly included a species in southern Queensland (Melville et al. 2007). 

As part of a revision of this species complex, Melville et al. (2019) made the unexpected finding that the lectotype of Tympanocryptis lineata (assigned by Wells and Wellington 1985) was applicable to a member of the T. pinguicolla complex, and that its universal association with a striped earless dragon was in error. 

These authors' work identified four species-level lineages within the group they consequently referred to "temperate grassland earless dragon group", and that the names T. lineata and T. pinguicolla referred to distinct species, the latter being applicable to the population from Victoria. The remaining two populations were described as the new species T. osbornei and T. mccartneyi.
Eucyclogobius newberryi was split into two and the southern portion of its range is now attributed to Eucyclogobius kristinae (Swift et al. 2016).

Hybridization of Sternotherus depressus with Sternotherus peltifer occurs in some areas along the periphery of the range of S. depressus, notably in the southern portion of its range (Mount 1981, Ernst et al. 1989, Scott and Rissler 2015, Scott et al. 2019).
Archaelogical remains suggest that Acipenser sturio colonised the Baltic Sea about 3,000 years ago from the North Sea, and vanished from the Baltic Sea about 800 years ago.
Asarcornis scutulata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Cairina.
Atelopus epikeisthos can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Lötters et al. 2004).
This is a split from the broader concept of Atelopus ebenoides (Rueda-Almonacid and Rueda-Martínez 2005)

authority: Reissig, Major, Renk, Barlow, Paijmans, Morris, Hofreiter, Broadley & Wüster, 2023
taxonomicNotes:
A previous Red List assessment for Hemachatus haemachatus (Alexander 2022) reported that the isolated subpopulation from the Nyanga District of Zimbabwe, known only from museum material, “appear to be morphologically different with lower ventral and subcaudal counts than those in South Africa”.

The subsequent recovery of a fragment of mitochondrial DNA from a preserved specimen confirmed that the Zimbabwean subpopulation is genetically and morphologically distinct from South African Rinkhals (Major et al. 2023), and these authors thus described the Zimbabwe subpopulation as a new species, Hemachatus nyangensis.
Pristis pristis was formerly known as P. perotteti in the Atlantic and sometimes in the Eastern Pacific, and P. microdon in the Indo-West Pacific. These are both now synonyms of P. pristis.

Photographed individuals from the Togean Archipelago, Indonesia were originally identified as Hippocampus satomiae Lourie and Kuiter 2008. They were later revealed as the Walea Soft Coral Pygmy Seahorse (H. waleananus) based on a single specimen from Walea Islands in the Togean Archipelago by Gomon and Kuiter 2009, citing differences in tail lengths, tail ring counts, and dorsal fin rays. Lourie et al. 2016 subsequently determined H. waleananus as a synonym of H. satomiae, given their lack of differences aside from those mentioned by Gomon and Kuiter (2009), and the fact that the locality of H. waleananus is completely within the distribution of H. satomiae. However, Short et al. 2018 have recognized H. waleananus as a distinct species based on its morphological characteristics, body ornamentations, host association, and behavior.

Kaipu’s Pipefish (Microphis kaipuae) was previously described as part of the genus Coelonotus (Haÿ et al. 2021). However, phylogenetic analysis by Haÿ, Mennesson, et al. (2023) revealed that five freshwater genera of the subfamily Nerophinae are polyphyletic. All freshwater genera of Nerophinae are therefore grouped under the genus Microphis Kaup 1853 as it is the first-described and most common genus of freshwater pipefish and several morphological characters common to Microphis species are shared within the monophyly (Haÿ Mennesson et al. 2023).
The taxonomic status of this species has recently been changed (Rakotoarison et al. 2017).
The taxonomic status of this species has been changed (Rakotoarison et al. 2017).

taxonomicNotes: This is the revised taxonomic concept of Rhynchobatus laevis, which excludes the population occurring around Japan and is now recognized as a separate species, Rhynchobatus mononoke Koeda, Itou, Yamada & Motomura, 2021.

The Common Blue Skate (Dipturus batis) and Flapper Skate (Dipturus intermedius) were synonymised in a taxonomic revision of European skates (Rajidae) in the 1920s (Clark 1926), before being recognised again as separate species in 2010 (Iglésias et al. 2010). Consequently, information for both species were reported as ‘Dipturus batis’ (the 'common skate complex') for much of the 20th and early 21st centuries.

This species was first described in 2017 (Nater et al. 2017). The Nater et al. study showed that an isolated orangutan population in the Batang Toru region, which is the southernmost range of extant Sumatran Orangutans (Pongo abelii), south of Lake Toba, is distinct from other Sumatran and Bornean populations. Through a comparison of cranio-mandibular and dental characters from an orangutan killed during human-orangutan conflict to 33 adult male orangutans of similar developmental stage, the study found consistent differences between the Batang Toru individual and other extant Ponginae. Model-based approaches based on the analyses of 37 orangutan genomes supported the morphological results by revealing that the deepest split in the evolutionary history of extant orangutans occurred ~3.38 Ma ago between the Batang Toru population and those to the north of Lake Toba, while both currently recognized species separated much later at about 674 ka. The analyses show that there was a small gene flow between P. abelii and P. tapanuliensis until 10–20 ka. The combined analyses support a new classification of orangutans into three extant species.

Although there is ongoing debate about the taxonomic status of the Bornean Orangutan (see review in Goossens et al. 2009); three subspecies are currently recognized for the taxon:

P. p. pygmaeus: Northwest Bornean Orangutan:
  • State of Sarawak (Malaysia)
  • Province of West Kalimantan (Indonesia)
P. p. wurmbii: Southwest Bornean Orangutan:
  • Province of West Kalimantan (Indonesia)
  • Province of Central Kalimantan (Indonesia)
P. p. morio: Northeast Bornean Orangutan:
  • State of Sabah (Malaysia)
  • Province of North Kalimantan (Indonesia)
  • Province of East Kalimantan (Indonesia)

Historically, the Sumatran and Bornean Orangutans were both considered to be subspecies of Pongo pygmaeus (e.g., Rijksen and Meijaard 1999). Recent taxonomic reviews (Groves 2001, Brandon-Jones et al. 2004) support the acceptance of the Sumatran Orangutan (Pongo abelii) as distinct from its Bornean relative (Pongo pygmaeus). This classification has since been widely adopted (e.g., Singleton et al. 2004). A recent study (Nater et al. 2017) proposed that the Batang Toru population is a separate species (Pongo tapanuliensis), and therefore this assessment does not include the orangutans in that area.

The taxonomy of this species has been disputed over the years. It was reclassified as Partula jackieburchi and then as Partula otaheitana rubescens by Johnson, Murray and Clarke (1986). Gerlach (2016) placed it in Partula.

Haas (1910) proposed the genus Pseudunio for this species, in order to distinguish it from M. margaritifera. Pseudunio was then synonymised by Ortmann (1911). Pseudunio was used again by Haas (1969) to distinguish P. auricularius and its "variety" P. auricularius marocanus (Pallary 1918) from the other species of the genus Margaritifera. More recently, the genus Pseudunio was used again by Smith (2001), Falkner et al. (2002) and Nienhuis (2003).

We now know (Araujo et al. 2009) that P. auricularius and P. marocanus are distinct species belonging to the same clade (thus monophyletic). Moreover, Vikhrev et al. (2017) redescribed "Margaritifera homsensis" (Lea, 1865) from specimens collected in Turkey, following the discovery of a few individuals living in the Karasu River, Orontes River Basin. The sequences produced by these authors are very close to those of P. auricularius in France and Spain, to the extent that these two populations could be considered as belonging to the same species regarding the molecular data (the authors discuss the reasons why they maintain the distinction between the two species).

Because the three species P. auricularius, P. homesensis and P. marocanus form a monophyletic clade and present a set of distinct ecological and morphological traits from the other species in the genus Margaritifera, the name Pseudunio was re-established by Lopes-Lima et al. (2018). Lyubas et al. (2019) consider the fossil species P. flabellatus from the Danube as the common ancestor of P. auricularius and P. homesensis.

Three subspecies of Banteng have come to be generally recognised (Lekagul and McNeely 1977, National Research Council 1983):
1. Bos javanicus javanicus on Java and Bali,
2. B. j. lowi on Borneo, and
3. B. j. birmanicus on the Asian mainland.

Grzimek (1990) argued against separating these local forms into true subspecies because a number of the small populations of wild Banteng which remain have been affected by interbreeding with domestic or feral cattle. Corbet and Hill (1992) did not recognise any valid subspecies of Banteng either. Frequent reports of interbreeding between wild Banteng and domestic livestock on Borneo (S. Hedges pers. comm. 2008) have yet to be substantiated in Sabah and Java (J. Burton pers. comm. 2016). Phylogenetic studies of B. j. lowi are confounded by the difficulties of obtaining samples. Recent genetic studies have produced contradicting results with regards to the taxonomic status of Banteng on Borneo. Mitochondrial DNA evidence suggested that the Bornean and Javan Banteng have such large genetic distances as to constitute separate species (Ishige et al. 2016, Handayani 2023). However, nuclear genomic data refutes this hypothesis and suggests that Bornean Banteng affiliates strongly with the Javan Banteng (Sun et al. 2022).

Until there is sufficient information on its genetic description, current population size, and status of B. j. lowi should not be included within B. javanicus. Pending further morphometric and genetic analysis Bos j. javanicus and B. j. birmanicus are provisionally accepted here in recognition of the relatively pronounced phenotypic differences which exist between Banteng on Java and the Asian mainland.
Two subspecies are recognized: Coleura seychellensis seychellensis from Mahé and Praslin, and C. s. silhouettae from Silhouette and La Digue (Hill 1971, Rocamora and Joubert 2004).
Three subspecies exist in Mexico: Peromyscus guardia guardia, P. g. harbisoni, and P. g. mejiae (Mellink and Luévano 2014).

An introduced subpopulation at Peppermint Bay hybridized with an existing subpopulation of dwarf cushion star (Parvulastra exigua). For 10 years, three separate forms could be identified as pure P. exigua, pure P. vivipara and a hybrid form (Parsons 2020). Recently, further hybridization has occurred and eventually there was a hybrid collapse, causing most specimens to now look like P. exigua. The identification of individuals from the most recent survey at this location exhibited typical P. vivipara morphological features but further testing is required to confirm these observations.

Specimens of this species were first collected in December 1982, when P. de Rham discovered a Nothobranchius population inland of the coastal Gazi village in the Gongoni Forest. The population was referred to as N. sp. Gazi (P. de Rham pers. comm.). Later, based on some resemblance in colouration, the population was mentioned as N. elongatus (de Rham 1991). The species was retrieved in van der Merwe et al. (2020) as a phylogenetically distinct lineage and referred to there as N. sp. Southern Kenya. Nothobranchius sylvaticus was established as a species by Nagy, Bellstedt and Luke (Bellstedt et al. 2025).

This species is closely related to Habromys chinanteco and H. simulatus. However, strong morphometric differentiation and geographic isolation help to differentiate the species (Romo-Vázquez et al. 2005).

Revisions of the taxonomy of genus Mobula included the decision to consider the circumglobal Spinetail Devil Ray M. japanica (Müller & Henle, 1841) a junior synonym of the Mediterranean Giant Devil Ray M. mobular (Bonnaterre, 1788), causing M. mobular to become a circumglobal species (Poortvliet et al. 2015, Hosegood et al. 2018, White et al. 2018).

Notarbartolo di Sciara et al. (2020) argued that one of the traits that were used to support the differentiation between the two species, the maximum size of M. mobular purportedly in excess of 5 m disc width (DW), can be explained by past misidentifications of M. birostris, and therefore unsubstantiated. This also supports their recommendation to retain for the species the common name “Spinetail Devil Ray” instead of “Giant Devil Ray”.
Pauxi unicornis and P. koepckeae (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. unicornis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
